comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
This is a bit weird - two negatives of the same view at the same time. I wonder if it was one of those stereoview shots?
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363523862/]

comment.author: 7726011@N07
comment._content: Here is an animated gif to help judge without eyestrain. Because the angle of view is different in each frame I am tempted to suggest this may have been an example of using a stereo camera to take two differently composed images so that the best could later be selected. (Resolution below: 372 x 491; Original resolution: 743 x 982)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
That is just amazing Thiophene_Guy.  Thanks for posting it, and even more technical details on your page.

I wonder if Charles Kerry, the photographer,  used the stereo camera elsewhere.  Maybe more almost identical images will pop up in the Tyrrell Collection.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Great find.  

I don't have a stereoviewer, but I'm going to try printing out the two photographs and place them side by side with a barrier between the two so I can view them separately, i.e. monocularly with each eye and see what happens.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/people/7726011@N07/] Brilliant stuff! Such a simple yet effective technique. I'm tempted to have some fun with my then and now photos ...

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] Thanks for the head's up on this one.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/13267298@N00] If you pull that off I'm sure your kid would find that super cool - I know I would! Soon you'll be making a pin-hole camera, and a camera obscura ...
